title: Environmental Protection Agency
harvest_method: CSV API, Ruby scripts with NOKOGIRI web crawler
harvest_notes:
Documentation by NB28VT:
Much of the data available at https://www3.epa.gov/enviro/ is easily accessible through an API.
That API is documented here: https://www.epa.gov/enviro/web-services
The Ruby-based API crawler (tools/table_crawler.rb) here writes individual tables in the EPA database to a CSV file in a specificied folder in the data directory

To grab data accessible through the API, you need the names of the tables in the EPA database. I've been using scrapers for this task.
The model pages (ex. https://www.epa.gov/enviro/greenhouse-gas-model) on the site include a clickable database diagram.
I've been crawling this page to get the table names. See tools/Air/greenhouse_gas_table_names.rb for an example scraper written in Ruby. 
To crawl the EPA and write to a destination in the database, simply initialize a TableCrawler with your table name and the destination folder.

title: Environmental Impact STatement (EIS) Database
harvest_notes:
we have generated a list of all the download links. domain in url.txt, relative paths to download links paths.txt, but the full data set is too large to download locally, paths and scraper script zipped and sent to a brendan (also included a zipped csv of the results table returned by the empty query which doesn't contain download links but is metadata, the links were found along with the rows in the table in the csv -- results.csv.zip)
 
the data set seems to be ordered by date, and when you go far enough out through the pages in the full result set there are no longer download links. the links in paths.txt seem to be a combination of EIS reports and something called Comment Letters. The comment letters go back further in history than the EIS. It seems like there are only EIS to download going back to around 2012, but comment letters going back to the early 2000s or late 90s, then the last many many pages of the result sets (going back to the mid 80s) do not have links for download, simply titles, some dates, and a link to a page like this: https://cdxnodengn.epa.gov/cdx-enepa-II/public/action/eis/details?eisId=88593

research says data is only accessible using search queries in a web form, but actually putting in a query with no params takes you to the full result set which can be scraped
harvest_method: scrape all download links on all the pages, write to txt file to be downloaded later (formatted for the wget tool in the repo)

title: National Service Center for Environmental Publications (NSCEP): Search Online Publication Title List
harvest_notes:
2/17/17 Because of the high number of links and the scraping policy at https://nepis.epa.gov/robots.txt,  we recommend these URLs be submitted to the End Of Term scraper for download.  It would take 211 hours to download if we complied with the 1 request per 10 seconds limit.  With so many files  it would be difficult to ensure we downloaded all of them successfully. 

Harvest method, script, and sample output at https://gist.github.com/janetriley/d83519c79c8caa88acea4653c0be7796
-jriley

2/18/17 Contacted Matt Price on the archiver slack.  He says the URLs should be submitted for crawling. He asked that I run the URLs through the harvesting toolkit url-check script to ensure the they aren't already on Internet Archives.  This will take a few days.  Checking the issue back out to me  for now.   -jriley

2/19/17 Passed the csv on to Matt Price for End of Term crawling.    Checked about 26K URLs through url-check in an overnight job.  Found about 0.7% were already archived.  Matt agreed it would put less load on the server to get an occasional repeat rather than check the remaining 50K.   Marking ticket as harvested.
harvest_method: We calculated the direct URL for the PDF from the links on pubtitle.html  .  We dumped the 76,300 rows to a CSV file, which is submitted here in the data directory.   We did not download any PDFs due to size of the site.  URLs submitted for End Of Term crawler.
bag_notes: Bagged with Data Conservancy Packaging tool; validated before S3 upload and after S3 download.

creator: XdmjtHzSPHBtPnoYh
seed_notes:
Dynamic data lookup by facility.  
Information on air releases is contained in ICIS-AIR, a computer-based repository for information about air pollution in the United States. This information comes from source reports by various stationary sources of air pollution, such as electric power plants, steel mills, factories, and universities, and provides information about the air pollutants they produce.

title: 2011 National Air Toxics Assessment (NATA) App
harvest_method: Went into the interface of the API and downloaded the full dataset, legend, layers of the map.
harvest_notes: I followed the project page ( https://www.epa.gov/national-air-toxics-assessment/2011-nata-assessment-results ) and got all the ZIP, PDF, and Excel files for the full dataset, methodology, and information about the project ( EPA 2011 National Air Toxics Assessment ).
bag_notes: Feb 24, 2017: This had already certified, but was not bagged or checked off.  There was no note found to explain why. Downloading the content and re-looking at it, the majority of these files are access databases in zip folders.  There are also layers for the interactive map.
describe_notes: Map's data can be accessed via ZIP code, specific address, and/or general place name (i.e.: New York City, Oklahoma).  Online interactive tools are functional.

creator: ZNC4b59EaL5W3edt7
title: Daily Outdoor Air Quality Data- Download Daily Data
harvest_method: Python script used to query for and capture each csv file
harvest_notes:
We grabbed all possible combinations of <pollutant>_<year>_<state>.csv. Also included is a file data/nodata.txt which lists all of the combinations which had no data available. When accessing the form https://www.epa.gov/outdoor-air-quality-data/download-daily-data directly, it should not be possible to choose any of the combinations listed in data/nodata.txt.

Note that if the scrape.py script is run again at a later date, the following lines should be removed:
# Remove 2017 from year_options
del year_options[0]

And you may also wish to delete some lines from data/nodata.txt, since downloads will only be attempted if the csv file does not exist and the file name is not present in data/nodata.txt

-BinaryMan32
